Body:
So you got the new iOS 7, huh? Believe it or not, under all that new flat prettyness lies a ton of neat new APIs and frameworks! I am going to briefly go into a new tool for iOS developers called UIKit Dynamics.

UIKit Dynamics is a full physics engine integrated into UIKit. Using UIKit Dynamics allows developers to create user interfaces that feel real. This means that UI objects can be considered physical objects that respond to gestures, touches, and changes to orientation. Developers may add behaviors such as gravity, attachments, and forces.

Want to see this in action? Go ahead and pull out your iPhone (sorry Android users!). On the lock screen there is a camera icon in the bottom right to allow you to quickly navigate to your camera app. Tap and hold on the icon and drag the screen almost half way up – now let go and watch what happens. Did you see the bounce effect at the bottom of the screen? Try again, but this time only drag the view up so you can just see the take picture button. You will notice there was even less bounce. Now the fun part. Do the same thing, but instead of just letting it go, swipe your finger toward the bottom of the screen like you’re throwing the view down. You will noticeably see a larger bounce from the view depending how fast you swiped the view and if you swipe it fast enough, it will bounce all the way up and launch the camera app!
